meta_data.title: Not Much Happened Between Chapter 1 and Chapter 2 of Esther, OTHER THAN THE FATE OF THE PLANET BEING DECIDED
meta_data.subtitle: Thanks to everyone who supports TMBH at  You're the reason we can all do this together!  Opening song, "" from the album, "" by

transcription_data.text: You're listening to the 10 minute Bible Hour podcast where we do fast, fun, free, daily deep dives into books of the Bible. And right now we're going through Esther. Hey, my friends, it's Matt. This is the 10 minute Bible Hour podcast. We just finished up Esther chapter one. It's a great prologue with intrigue and mystery set against the backdrop of the golden age of Persia, resplendent in its wealth and its beauty and its extravagance, but just underneath all of that gilded surface lies a seedy underbelly of tension and manipulation and sneaky power plays happening, even amongst the people closest to the great king of lands, the king of kings, the king of earth and water, Xerxes, king of Persia, who ruled from his throne in Sousa. We wrap things up with him making a rash decision and sending this decision out to everybody everywhere. He makes this big proclamation and it's funny the way it's presented. I don't know. I think I touched on that just a little bit at the end of the last episode, but note that the book of Esther is funny. It's a different kind of humor than what you get in movies and TV shows and stuff today, but it's there. And notice how in the last lines at the end of chapter one, Xerxes is upset because what are we going to do if word gets out that my wife disrespecting me, bad things are going to happen. And then the end of the prologue three different ways says how absolutely thoroughly he addressed that concern by sending out a message to everyone in the kingdom, an official royal decree in all languages to all people written in all scripts to make sure everybody knew exactly what happened. That'll help keep it under wraps. It's supposed to be funny and the curtain closes on this opening prologue. I don't think you can call it act one. I think you could picture it as the material right before the opening credits and maybe the opening theme runs. And all of this is happening in 483 BC. The third year of his reign is when this big party, this war council happens. Well, the curtains close at the end of chapter one. And as is so often the case after a prologue time passes and some really big stuff happens between chapter one and chapter two. So let's say you we see all the actors in the art and the credits and everything else that rolls right there. And then the screen goes black for a minute and maybe you can hear the sounds of the royal court or plates clinking in the background hubbub and buzz, birds chirping, whatever it might be. But you don't see anything yet. And instead you just see on the screen four years later, Xerxes has returned to his palace in Susa, a defeated man, his reputation and shambles after a shameful defeat at the hand of the Greeks. Something like that. That's pretty pro Greek anti-Persia bias that I just threw on that. But you can picture that in a movie, right? You can picture that as being a passage of time. Well between chapter one and chapter two, so much happened. The histories by Herodotus that I've been leaning on so heavily. It is once again this thick. Wait for it. Just hang on. Just a minute. All right. A little bit more. Hang on. It's just about got it. Keep listening. Don't go anywhere. It's that thick and we are finally getting to the very, very end of it. I think they were like dust mites or something in there. It's a huge story covering all these things we've been talking about it. But between chapter one and chapter two, we burned through most of that material. We're basically at the end of that story now. And what happens in the interim is Xerxes does exactly what he was told to do in those three visions. Well, two for him and one for his buddy dressed up like him, Artubanos. And the force is described over the course of pages and pages of Herodotus's work. It's that big a deal just all these military units from all these different parts of the world. There's a huge chunk that Herodotus gives us that is just dedicated to Xerxes sending out an advanced company of engineers to dig a canal across this peninsula that mount Athos is on. Apparently that had been hard on his dad. Ships had crashed there on his way to his eventual defeat at Marathon or on his army's way to their eventual defeat. And so Xerxes was going to make a show of things and he was going to demonstrate this is what happens when the king of Persia shows up. Things get better and projects get done and they get done quickly. Oh, and also dissidents get punished. And so this thing gets dug. You can still apparently see it today. It's not functional. It's silt it in, but it's still there. It's visible. I looked at Google Maps. You can tell. So before Xerxes even goes on this trek, he is already making his mark in 482 and 481 in 481. He loads up and does the cross country journey clear out West past his Asia minor modern day Turkey capital of Sardis. It's not technically a capital, but it functions like one because it's his most prominent Western most city. He goes through Sardis and he crosses over into Europe and Herodotus tells us everything's going according to plan and people are bending the knee to him. And then he runs into a buzz saw in the form of 300 Spartans and a few of their buddies at the pass at Thermopylae on the way down toward Athens. And the Spartans aren't numerous enough to win, but they're numerous enough to hold that pass for a real long time to provide strategic advantage for the Athenians who've got a great big fleet and a whole bunch of refugees. They need to get out of Athens waiting just down the coast a few miles. Well, eventually some local Greek sells out the Spartans and the Persians are able to get in behind them and they wipe them out and they cut Lee and Idison half. They put his body on a couple of poles on either side of the pass at Thermopylae to make a point. And now Xerxes is heading for Athens and he goes to Athens. And Athens has been abandoned because they knew they couldn't hold it. So he burns the Acropolis and makes a point out of things, but the Athenians are just still right there in the bay by Athens. They're being shuttled about by this big fleet. The Athenians have built and Xerxes is not satisfied that the punishment is done. He wants to wipe them out. So he puts a chair up on a hill and picks a place after being duped into an ill-advised naval battle that he loses badly in the Straits of Salamis to the Athenian politician, general and admiral Themistocles. And Xerxes ends up having to turn around and go home. He leaves behind the general Mardonius, you remember? That's the guy who back at the wedding party in Esther chapter one, he's not mentioned in Esther, but he was at the party. He may even have been one of those nobles who had unlimited access to the king, who was mentioned there at the end of Esther chapter one, heck man, maybe he's Memukon. Who knows? These names exist in multiple different languages and only occasionally can we get them to line up and correspond. But the point is this guy was elite. He was Persian nobility and he was all in on the Athens campaign idea during the war council party. We read about in Esther chapter one. So Xerxes is like, all right, well, you were in on this too. I'm going to leave you behind to clean up this mess. But Mardonius does anything but clean up that mess. Instead, he meets a Greek alliance in battle at Plataea and not only does he lose, but he dies in that battle. And that is the end of the Persians asserting themselves in Greek territory. In fact, the way it works out is for about the next 140 years, things sit in stalemate between the basically the Greek world and basically the Persian world until finally a Greek ish guy from up north of the Greek areas we've been talking about. The son of Philip II, Alexander III of Macedon, the great decides that he wants to go and conquer Persia himself, conquer the other way that is take the fight to them. And from the mid toward the late 300s, Alexander the Great does exactly that, defeating some distant descendant of Xerxes named Darius III in battle. And effectively, Alexander the Great is the last emperor of the Achaemenid Empire to really spike the football. Alexander the Great even marries Darius III's kid. So in a way, he marries into the Achaemenid dynasty and is effectively the last emperor of Persia because after he died without naming an heir, all of the Alexandrian conquered world got divided up amongst his generals. So that's how things kind of play out with the whole Greece versus Persia thing. And that just leaves us with one question relative to our story. Well, how is Xerxes doing? How are things going for him? You know, it's a it's a tough stretch. He had a falling out with his wife in front of everybody probably after he's sobered up, he realized that wasn't the best decree ever to send out. Probably felt pretty good to get out of dodge and go on a road trip with your buddies. It would have been a lot more fun if you could have won the war, but whatever is a great king, king of kings, right? And we find out from Herodotus that he has some hijinks on the trip back home and we get a sense of what kind of man Herodotus at least believed he was. And tomorrow we're going to talk about post Greek campaign Xerxes and where his head might have been as we roll into chapter two. I appreciate you. I'm Matt. This is a 10 minute Bible hour podcast. Let's do this again soon. This podcast exists because many of you kick in to make it happen even though you don't have to. Learn more at thetmbh.com slash support.
